awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exploring Low-Latitude Ionospheric Irregularities in the Upper E-Region Valley Using Observations, Theory, And Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal combines modeling tools with incoherent scatter radar measurements to investigate the sources of radar echoes scattered from the equatorial ionosphere near 150 km. When plotted in the altitude-time plane, these echoes resemble a "necklace". Intricately structured backscatter first appears at dawn near 150 km, descends to ~130 km by midday, lofts to150 km by late afternoon, and disappears at sunset. The cause of these echoes remained largely unknown until 2016, when the PIs plausibly argued they were manifestations of photoelectron-driven electron waves. The goal of this work is to build a cohesive, physics-based, system-science understanding of the 150-km echoes. 
Under this new award, the PIs will continue their theoretical and experimental investigations by incorporating additional processes into their model, and comparing with Jicamarca radar and ionosonde data. Broader impacts include mentoring of graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students. Advancing understanding of ionospheric physics, and being able to interpret ionospheric radar signatures and ionospheric structuring benefits space weather modeling and prediction. The 2016 work received much attention in the popular press, and thus stimulated public interest in plasma physics research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project used theory and large-scale simulations to explore the physics of the lower ionosphere.  One objective was to explain the physics underling echoes detected by VHF radars at around 150-km altitude every day near the geomagnetic equator.  In this, it has succeeded rather dramatically, putting together both a theoretical model with simulations to show that photoelectrons will energize waves in regions essentially exactly where the echoes originate (see, Longley, et al,. 2020; The Photoelectron‐Driven Upper Hybrid Instability as the Cause of 150‐km Echoes in Geophys. Res. Lett., ).  One question that remains is: how these electron waves then stimulate the much slower ion waves that create the radar signal.  This project also made great progress in developing our understanding of electrojet waves, which also create strong radar signals and, through their nonlinear properties, impact the conductance of the geospace environment.  More specifically, this work studied the combined gradient-drift and Farley-Buneman instabilities that trigger turbulence and non-linear behaviors.  

This project had broader impacts through the training of students from the k-12 level to the Ph.D. level in the scientific method and computer technologies.  This grant supported two Ph.D. students and two undergraduate students. Both of those Ph.D. students, have completed their Ph.D., graduated and obtained professional positions as research scientists. One undergraduate student graduated in May 2019 with honors and has 1 first author paper accepted at a prestigious journal. She is now working toward her Ph.D. at UCLA.  In 2019, we worked last summer with a high school student last summer, training them to analyze radar data.  Over the summer of 2020, we had 2 undergraduate students working with us one is learning basic scientific programing and the other is helping with theoretical aspects of this research.  Over summer 2021, another student, began working with us.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2021
Modified by: Meers Oppenheim
